title: Astounded by Paul VanderKlay, Complexity theory, randomness and anomaly
description:
Karl graduated from U. C. Berkeley in Engineering Physics, spent 24 years in Air Force as a fighter pilot, American but grew up in France, lived in the U. S., France, the UK, Korea and Germany, plus many other countries.
Loves Philosophy, science,
Astounded by Paul VanderKlay and his openness and depth of interest.
Complexity theory and emergence
Requires just the right amount of randomness.
Order imposed from the top will eventually collapse a complex system.  This is why Marxism and Fascism were doomed to fail and why they did so much damage in the 20th century.
Initially exposed to complexity from reading Friedrich Hayek, spontaneous order out of human action, not human design.
Karl Popper - we are a universe open to novelty.
The randomness we observe may at times reflect our ignorance of deeper explanations.
Recently reading Stuart Kauffman’s Reinventing the Sacred.
Likes Roger Penrose, doesn’t like the ideas of Donald Hoffman
Philip Dick’s definition of reality, “that which when you stop believing in it, still doesn’t go away.”
He accepts the reality of God #1, a non-active God, the immutable laws of the universe, the Logos (logic) to which we are all subject.
He believes that when rational consciousness arose, there was not a new branch of normative law. The human-made positive law is supposed to reflect the natural law, but he says the only place in the world that has formally codified that is the United States.
